item.title: 50 Years on, Bloody Sunday’s Wounds Are Still Felt
item.description: A half-century after the killings in Northern Ireland, symbols of division and hostility still hold their potency.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell

item.title: As Russian Troops Mass in Belarus, a Ukraine Border Is Largely Undefended
item.description: From the border, it’s a fast 140 miles down a newly paved highway to Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, but only a few troops stand guard.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The E-95 highway from Chernihiv toward Kyiv.

item.title: In Canada, ‘Freedom Convoy’ Protesting Vaccine Mandates Nears Capital
item.description: The “Freedom Convoy” had driven across Canada to reach the capital. The demonstrations on Saturday were raucous but largely peaceful.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters around Parliament Hill in downtown Ottawa on Saturday.

item.title: Italian Lawmakers Re-Elect Sergio Mattarella as President, Preserving Status Quo
item.description: Mr. Mattarella has presided over a chaotic seven years in which the country swung wildly from the left to the right, acting as the guardrails of Italy’s democracy.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: President Sergio Mattarella of Italy was elected to another term on Saturday.

item.title: ISIS Siege of Syria Prison Proves It's Still a Threat
item.description: The Islamic State may no longer be able to control territory, but it has shown in Syria and Iraq that it can still pull off opportunistic military operations.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kurdish militia fighters warming themselves on Friday near a prison in Hasaka, Syria, that Islamic State fighters had attacked.

item.title: India’s Militarized Nagaland Calls for End to Army Impunity
item.description: A deadly mistaken ambush by soldiers seeking rebels in the country’s northeast has renewed attention on a special powers act that residents say perpetuates fear and harassment.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Charred vehicles, torched during protests, at the site where Indian Army Special Forces shot and killed a group of ethnic Naga villagers near Oting, India, in December.

item.title: White House Warnings Over Russia Strain Ukraine-U.S. Partnership
item.description: While Ukraine’s president complained about “acute and burning” warnings from Washington, the Pentagon issued a dire new appraisal asserting Russia has amassed enough troops to invade his entire country.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers training in the Volnovakha district in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: On Patrol: 12 Days With a Taliban Police Unit in Kabul
item.description: Tasked with guarding a Shiite shrine, a police unit offers a telling snapshot of the Taliban’s rank-and-file fighters and the challenges Afghanistan’s rulers face in governing a diverse nation.
item.dc:creator: Victor J. Blue, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Safiullah Padshah
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taliban fighter Zahed, assigned to guard the Sakhi Shrine, a Shia mosque and shrine, rides in their truck in the Kart-e-Sakhi neighborhood of Kabul, Afghanistan.

item.title: Pentagon Warns of Russia's Troop Deployments Near Ukraine
item.description: Russia has massed more than 100,000 troops at Ukraine’s borders, officials said, publicly confirming what intelligence analysts have described for weeks.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: At a news conference on Friday, Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III, left, and Gen. Mark A. Milley presented a grim picture of the events on the Ukrainian border.

item.title: After 600 Years, Swiss City at Last Has a Woman on Night Watch
item.description: Lausanne has kept a night watch atop its cathedral since 1405, but it never appointed a woman to the role until Cassandre Berdoz, after a long fight, landed a job that was her “childhood dream.”
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:credit: Clara Tuma for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cassandre Berdoz, 28, is the first woman ever appointed to the role of night watch in Lausanne, Switzerland.

item.title: South Korea Indicts Defector From the North Over Leaflets
item.description: South Korea banned the spreading of leaflets across the border last year. Park Sang-hak, an outspoken activist who defied the ban, was indicted this week.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Park Sang-hak at his office in Seoul. He is the first person to be indicted on charges of breaking a new law banning the spread of propaganda leaflets along the inter-Korean border.

item.title: Tonga’s Diaspora Confronts Daunting Challenge of Disaster Response
item.description: Tens of thousands of overseas Tongans, intimately tied to their homeland, are contending with the pandemic, snarled supply chains and limited communications.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mary Lyn Fonua/Matangi Tonga/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Ash covered a street in Nuku’alofa, Tonga’s capital, on Jan. 16, the day after a volcanic eruption and tsunami struck the country.

item.title: Burkina Faso and 5 Other Coups in Africa, Explained
item.description: Burkina Faso this week joined a list of countries that have recently experienced military takeovers — most plagued by insecurity, poor governance and frustrated youth. But there’s no one-size-fits-all explanation.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crowds gathered in the main plaza in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso on Tuesday, a day after the military announced their takeover on state television.

item.title: Police Investigation Could Give Boris Johnson a Lifeline in Party Scandal
item.description: A request by the police that a senior civil servant investigating parties in Downing Street during the lockdown withhold details from her report could give the British prime minister time to regroup.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, center, on his way to 10 Downing Street this week. Parties held at Downing Street have put enormous political pressure on the British leader.

item.title: North Korea’s Latest Missile Test Appears to Be Its Boldest in Years
item.description: Flight data indicates that a launch carried out Sunday was the North’s most powerful since 2017. South Korea said the projectile was an intermediate-range ballistic missile.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Watching coverage of North Korea’s latest missile launch in Seoul on Sunday.

item.title: Putin Has Long Tried to Balance Europe. Now He’s Working to Reset It.
item.description: After years of trying to diplomatically divide and conquer, the Russian leader has seemingly decided to antagonize Europe as a whole in the current Ukraine crisis.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: Carrying a howitzer shell on Wednesday during Russian Army drills in the region bordering Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. Sanctions Aimed at Russia Could Take a Wide Toll
item.description: The boldest measures that President Biden is threatening to deter an invasion of Ukraine could roil the entire Russian economy — but also those of other nations.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:description: Sanctions could be viewed as punishing the Russian people — a perception that might fuel President Vladimir V. Putin’s narrative that his country is being persecuted by the West.

item.title: How France's Macron Is Approaching the Ukraine Situation
item.description: The French president, determined to engage with Russia, wants to shape a new European security order from crisis — and win the April election.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at his Fort of Brégançon presidential summer residence in 2019.

item.title: Is It OK to Watch the Winter Games? A Former Olympian Weighs In.
item.description: This year’s Winter Olympics come in the midst of widespread human rights abuses in China and a low point in Canada’s relations with the country.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, the leader of China, planned the Winter Olympics as a showcase of the country under his rule.

item.title: ‘My Soul Is Crying’: Ukrainians Remember a Deadly Rocket Attack
item.description: Residents in Mariupol, a Ukrainian front-line city rocked by shelling in 2015, mourn the dead as they brace for a potential Russian escalation.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Brent McDonald, Andriy Dubchak and Dmitriy Khavin

item.title: U.S. Blocks $130 Million in Aid for Egypt Over Rights Abuses
item.description: The Middle Eastern ally continues to buy billions of dollars worth of military equipment from the United States.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Mona El-Naggar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry of Egypt spoke by phone on Thursday.

item.title: Canadian Truck Convoys Head to Ottawa to Protest Vaccine Mandate
item.description: Truckers from across the country aim to converge at on Saturday outside of Parliament to protest federal vaccination mandates.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Truckers drove through Toronto on Thursday on their way to Ottawa, the Canadian capital, to protest Covid vaccination requirements for those who cross the U.S. border.

item.title: U.S. Says Russian Gas Line to Germany Will Be Blocked If War Comes
item.description: The pipeline to Germany would expand Russia’s capacity to sell gas to Europe, which is already highly dependent on Russian energy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: A Russian pipe-laying ship, working on construction of the Nord Stream 2, moored at the Mukran Port on the island of Ruegen, Germany, in 2020.

item.title: Separatists Kill 10 Pakistani Soldiers in Attack on Outpost
item.description: The assault was one of the deadliest on Pakistani security forces in recent years and comes at a time of heightened unrest.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Funeral prayers on Thursday for one of the 10 soldiers killed in an attack in the Kech district of Pakistan’s Baluchistan Province.

item.title: Francis Bacon's Animal Paintings, Analyzed by Animal Experts
item.description: A new exhibition at London’s Royal Academy highlights Francis Bacon’s paintings of animals. We showed them to some specialists in their subject matter.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: Record Payout Awarded to Sexual Abuse Victims in India
item.description: The case, involving rapes at a shelter for homeless girls, signals a partial reckoning with the government’s responsibility in an epidemic of sexual violence.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Emily Schmall
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A protest in New Delhi in July 2018 in response to reports of sexual abuse at a shelter for homeless girls in the north Indian state of Bihar.

item.title: ISIS Fighters Get Ultimatum in Syria Prison Standoff
item.description: The U.S.-backed Syrian Democratic Forces militia demanded that about 60 ISIS militants, still holed up in a prison a week after they attacked it, give themselves up or risk being killed.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Sangar Khaleel
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kurdish-led fighters detained a man near the prison whom they identified as an ISIS foreign fighter. They said they suspected he was from Saudi Arabia.

item.title: The U.K. police ask that some details be omitted from a report on Downing Street parties during a lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, center, on his way to 10 Downing Street this week.

item.title: How Pegasus's Spyware Changed Global Intelligence
item.description: A tale about Israel, Pegasus and the world.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A Pegasus facility in Sapir, Israel.

item.title: A South Korean naval unit quarantines in Oman after a Covid outbreak on their ship.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Sameer Yasir and Jason Gutierrez
item.media:description: The South Korean Navy’s destroyer Wang Geon, carrying a contingent of the Cheonghae Unit, departing a naval base in Busan, South Korea.

item.title: F.B.I. Secretly Bought Israeli Spyware and Explored Hacking U.S. Phones
item.description: Israel used the NSO Group’s software as a tool of diplomacy. The F.B.I. wanted it for domestic surveillance. Then everything soured. Here are highlights of a New York Times Magazine investigation.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: The Israeli cyber company NSO Group at one of its branches in the Arava Desert in Sapir, Israel.

item.title: The Battle for the World’s Most Powerful Cyberweapon
item.description: A Times investigation reveals how Israel reaped diplomatic gains around the world from NSO’s Pegasus spyware — a tool America itself purchased but is now trying to ban.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Mark Mazzetti
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Alarming Levels of Mercury Are Found in Old Growth Amazon Forest
item.description: The findings, related to gold mining in Peru, provide new evidence of how people are altering ecosystems in dangerous ways around the world.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:description: An improvised dredging system near Puerto Maldonaldo, in the Madre de Dios region of Peru, extracted gold using mercury.

item.title: World Surpasses 10 Billion Covid Vaccine Doses Administered
item.description: Some nations can now envision a near future in which their people coexist with the virus but aren’t confined by it.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Getting vaccinated against the coronavirus in Brazil this month.

item.title: Russia Says U.N. Security Council Meeting Is Just a U.S. Stunt
item.description: U.S. officials see the meeting, scheduled for Monday, as a chance to expose Russia to criticism on a global stage. They expressed confidence that it would go ahead as planned.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: A meeting of the United Nations Security Council in New York last year.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Russia mulls a response to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on the frontline in Popasna, eastern Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Includes European Allies As He Confronts Putin On Ukraine
item.description: In what amounts to a much-needed diplomatic reset, the U.S. is orchestrating the response to Russia’s threatening moves and making sure to include his European allies.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Steven Erlanger and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The Ukrainian army at the front line.

item.title: Let’s Talk Tennis, and Politics
item.description: This year’s Australian Open was controversial even before it started. How’s it going now?
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Two spectators wearing “Where is Peng Shuai?” T-shirts in the Australian Open stands on Tuesday.

item.title: Sarah Palin, Who is Unvaccinated, Dined Outdoors in N.Y.C. After Testing Positive
item.description: The unvaccinated former Alaska governor returned to Elio’s, the Upper East Side restaurant where she had been seen dining indoors on Saturday despite the city’s requirement that indoor guests show proof of vaccination.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.media:description: Sarah Palin tested positive for the coronavirus and was seen dining out in New York City, where people who test positive are asked to isolate for five days.

item.title: Vice President Harris Seeks Ally in Honduras as She Revisits Central America
item.description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s trip was viewed as more than just showcasing the U.S. presence at the inauguration of Xiomara Castro, the first female head of state in Honduras.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris attended the presidential inauguration of Xiomara Castro in Honduras on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Voices Pessimism About U.S. Response
item.description: A Kremlin spokesman said there was “not much cause for optimism.”
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Russian T-72B3 tanks during drills this month at the Kadamovskiy firing range in southern Russia on Wednesday.

item.title: Gunman Kills 5 at Ukraine Rocket Factory, Adding to Tensions
item.description: Little was known about the shooting at the aerospace plant, but it came amid concerns about sabotage.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Mykhailo Markiv/Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via Reuters
item.media:description: The Yuzhmash factory in 2014 in Dnipro, Ukraine.

item.title: India Pandemic School Closings Imperil 'Demographic Dividend'
item.description: A large proportion of working-age people, once seen as a demographic advantage, could turn into a burden if many of them are undereducated and underemployed.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ishita and Rudra attending school online. A classroom the size of a phone is not ideal, but at least they have internet access. Many in India do not.

item.title: Johnson Vows to Release Full Report on Lockdown Parties
item.description: The findings of an inquiry into the parties at Downing Street have yet to be made public. Information that may compromise a police investigation is currently being removed from the report.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle

item.title: ‘We’ve Been Through This Before’: Ukraine City Braces for Possible Russian Invasion
item.description: Flanked by rebel combatants and Russian forces to the east and Russian ships to the south, Mariupol is one place where President Vladimir Putin’s forces could attack first, or stage a provocation. We speak to residents and soldiers on the front line in this Ukrainian city.
item.dc:creator: Brent McDonald, Yousur Al-Hlou, Dmitriy Khavin, Andriy Dubchak, Christiaan Triebert, Brenna Smith and Aaron Byrd

item.title: Botched Airstrikes Prompt U.S. Military Orders to Protect Civilians
item.description: A new directive outlines steps intended to change how commanders think about their jobs, after New York Times investigations into botched airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Charlie Savage and Azmat Khan
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Yuri Gripas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III’s directive comes after Congress imposed restrictions on some military funds until the Pentagon submits a new civilian casualty policy.

item.title: Jordan’s Army Kills 27 in Drug Bust on Syrian Border
item.description: The Jordanian Army said that soldiers fired on suspected smugglers as they tried to cross the border under cover of a snowstorm.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Jordanian soldiers patrolling along the border with Syria in 2017.

item.title: A #MeToo Moment Shakes Israel’s Ultra-Orthodox
item.description: An acclaimed religious children’s author was accused of abusing women and children. Then he killed himself, sending shock waves through the conservative community.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bookshop still selling books by the author Chaim Walder, who killed himself after being accused of sexual abuse, in an ultra-Orthodox neighborhood in the city of Bnei Brak, Israel.

item.title: A ‘NATO Nerd’ Thrown Into the Crisis Over Russia and Ukraine
item.description: Julianne Smith is the new U.S. ambassador to NATO, a post empty for a year, trying to consult and lead while bandaging the wounds of the Trump years.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Valentin Bianchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It’s hard enough to get 30 people to agree on a restaurant,” Julianne Smith likes to say about NATO. “So it has its challenges.”

item.title: Germany Draws Mockery for Promising 5,000 Helmets to Help Ukraine
item.description: Critics saw it as a sign of Germany’s reticence to confront Russia. One asked: “What support are they going to send next? Pillows?”
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Germany’s defense minister, Christine Lambrecht, last month in Lithuania.

item.title: The Ending of 'Fight Club' Was Censored in China
item.description: The 1999 cult classic starring Brad Pitt and Edward Norton is not the only foreign film to be altered for audiences in mainland China.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Brad Pitt in a scene from “Fight Club,” released in 1999. A version of the film on a streaming service in China features a different, less violent ending.

item.title: U.S.-Backed Forces Clash With ISIS Fighters at Syrian Prison
item.description: The Kurdish-led militia claimed prematurely it had retaken a prison captured by the Islamic State. In fact, the battle continues. Up to 90 ISIS fighters remain.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Sangar Khaleel
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman and her two boys emerged from their home on Thursday as Kurdish special forces conducted house-to-house searches for escaped prisoners and ISIS fighters in Hasaka, Syria.

item.title: Covid Case in Beijing Olympic Bubble Is Linked to a German Team
item.description: A supervisor who tested positive is asymptomatic and is now in a quarantine hotel, the German Olympic Sports Confederation said.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Inside the Olympic main media center, which is part of the Olympic Covid-19 “bubble,” in Beijing this week.

item.title: Justice Breyer's Retirement and His Impact on the Supreme Court
item.description: The latest on the coming Supreme Court nomination.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Stephen Breyer at home in 2015.

item.title: Why Is Everyone Going to the Dominican Republic?
item.description: The country is a rare pandemic success story, with recent visitor numbers far surpassing those of most other Caribbean destinations. Easy entry rules are a draw, but some residents are uneasy.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:description: Unlike many other Caribbean beach destinations, the Dominican Republic doesn’t require proof of vaccination, test results or quarantine for most incoming travelers. Above, a scene in Punta Cana, one of the most popular spots.

item.title: Can Biden Avert a Crisis With North Korea?
item.description: Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, has done six missile tests this month — equal to all of 2021 — and called on the nation to prepare for “long-term confrontation.”
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: North Korea fired off two cruise missiles on Tuesday in a fifth weapons test this year.

item.title: How Putin Is Using Russia’s Military as a Tool for Foreign Policy
item.description: A significantly upgraded military has emerged as a key tool of Vladimir Putin’s foreign policy, as he flexes his might around the globe and, most ominously, on the Ukraine border.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Michael Schwirtz and Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Russian T-72B3 tanks during drills this month at the Kadamovskiy firing range in southern Russia.

item.title: Yes, Omicron Is Loosening Its Hold. But the Pandemic Has Not Ended.
item.description: With spotty immunity in the population and a churn of new variants, the coronavirus is likely to become a persistent but hopefully manageable threat.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Allison Zaucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Early in the pandemic, some estimated that vaccinating about 70 percent of the population might lead to herd immunity. But the more contagious a variant, the higher the percentage of vaccinated people required to reach the threshold.

item.title: Ukraine Police Arrest Suspect in Military Factory Shooting
item.description: The authorities identified the man as a young national guard soldier and said he opened fire on fellow soldiers “for undetermined reasons.” The site has been a focus of weapons proliferation concerns.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Near the Yuzhmash factory in 2017 in Dnipro, Ukraine. Five people were killed on Thursday after a national guard soldier opened fire in a guardhouse there, the authorities said.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Diplomatic attempts to resolve the situation with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken.
